Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Programming Nucleic Acids Self-Assembly

The objective of this proposal is to develop platforms for engineering programmable synthetic molecular devices self-assembled from nucleic acid molecules (DNA and RNA), and for exploiting these devices to do useful molecular work. In this research, these devices are composed of small synthetic nucleic acid monomers capable of conditional configuration change, and can be programmed to self-assemble, move, and compute. When coupled with other functional molecules, such as fluorophores and proteins, they could potentially serve as dynamic controllers for the spatial arrangement and, hence the collective function, of such molecules. This will enable the development of diverse applications in imaging, sensing, diagnostics, and therapeutics. Specifically, the proposed research will (1) develop computational tools to facilitate the design of these molecular devices, (2) experimentally construct DNA and RNA molecular devices that demonstrate prescribed dynamic behaviors, and (3) exploit such molecular devices for diverse biomedical applications.

Integrated research and education plans will be pursued to provide interdisciplinary training for postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students. New curriculum on molecular engineering will be developed to benefit the Harvard graduate and undergraduate population. Field trip to the PI?s lab will be hosted to help excite students from a local high school with a majority minority population about careers in science and engineering. An international undergraduate biomolecular design and engineering competition will be launched to help expose students around world with research experience in biomolecular nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Programming Nucleic Acids Self-Assembly

Biology inspires a vision for information technology programmed via molecular technology. Using essentially the same “hardware”, i.e. primarily the programmable chemistry of nucleic and amino acids, the digital information in the genome specifies the development and operation of gigantic molecular systems that we call living organisms. By programming a user friendly “molecular controller”, human beings could specify and realize their functional needs in the molecular world.

Working towards this long term goal, the Yin lab focuses on engineering synthetic molecular devices, which self-assemble from this digital DNA/RNA informational material. These devices are composed of small synthetic monomers that can be programmed to self-assemble, move, and compute. When coupled with other functional molecules, such as other DNA, RNA, proteins or fluorescent molecules, they can potentially serve as programmable controllers for the spatial arrangement, re-arrangement, and thus, the function of such molecules. This enables the development of new applications in imaging, sensing, diagnostics and therapeutics, which can be used in the fight for cancer and other diseases.

During this project, we developed and demonstrated various methods to first, design and assemble rigid 2D and 3D molecular structures with user-defined shapes and sizes, second, automate the kinetic pathway design and manipulation of these prescribed shapes and third, exploit such kinetic systems to develop applications for biomedical imaging and therapeutics. Furthermore, we were able to achieve our original goals and complete the project earlier than anticipated.

Intellectual Merit

By developing new approaches in synthetic molecular self-assembly, we were able to build rigid 2D and 3D molecular structures with arbitrary shape, which self-assemble in a triggered and isothermal fashion, while following specifically designed kinetic reaction pathways. We demonstrated this process by assembling polyhedral structures of different geometries and sizes. We also developed methods to recapitulate the temporal and spatial order of self-assembly observed in many biological developmental processes. We then demonstrate this via the rational design of kinetically controlled isothermal synthesis of DNA tetrahedrons with well-defined 3D wireframe structures. Together, these enable the construction of a “developmental” self-assembly system, where a synthetic structure “grows” following defined kinetic assembly pathways, with some reactions occurring sequentially and others simultaneously, ultimately developing into the desired complex structure.

We contributed to the emergence of a new direction in computer science that is becoming known as “molecular programming”, where programs are written to direct the behavior of physical molecules. We build from abstraction methods used in the field of computer science to automate the design process. Users can correctly embed a structure with prescribed functions. Considering the scale at which we can now synthesize our 2D and 3D structures, this greatly facilitate the design process and enables non-experts to design their own functional shapes.

Our new imaging methods open new doors for biomedical research. Our synthetic molecular devices with programmable structure, function and kinetics were exploited as molecular instruments for imaging and smart diagnostics. We challenged competing imaging technologies by demonstrating a nearly unlimited multiplexing super-resolution imaging method with nanometer precision. This is essential for studying biological phenomena at a scale relevant to the cellular environment.

We also reported on a class of de-novo-designed riboregulators, called toehold switches, which activate gene expression in response to cognate RNA signal with arbitrary sequences. Toehold switches provide a high level of orthogonality and can be forward engineered to provide high dynamic ranges. We showed that these switches could be integrated into the genome to regulate endogenous genes and be used as sensors that respond to endogenous RNA triggers. We exploited the orthogonality of the toehold switches to regulate multiple genes independently and to construct a genetic computing circuit that evaluates 4-input AND logic gates. This work later formed the basis for the development of an Ebola and a Zika paper-based diagnostics by our colleagues.

Broader Impacts

Our Integrative research and education plans provided interdisciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students, and postdocs, some of them have successfully transitioned to faculty and management positions in academia and industry. New curriculum development, such as Harvard’s SB204 Biomolecular Engineering and Synthetic Biology”, provides up-to-date curriculum benefiting the wider Harvard graduate and undergraduate population. Field trips to the lab with students from Mission Hill School, a local majority minority public school in Boston, were very exciting and generated a lot of enthusiasm about careers in science and engineering. We were directly involved in launching BIOMOD, an international college-level biomolecular engineering design competition, which exposed students around world to research experience in DNA and protein nanotechnologies. During the duration of this project, our lab generated 21 scientific publications, which were reprised numerous times by various media targeting a broader audience. Finally, our work led to the founding of two venture-backed startups, which we hope will benefit cancer research.
